Article.ArticleTitle: Associations between daily mortality in London and combined oxidant capacity, ozone and nitrogen dioxide.

AbstractText: Both nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>) and ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) are powerful oxidants in ambient air that are intimately linked through atmospheric chemistry and which continuously interchange over very short timescales. Based upon atmospheric chemistry alone, there is a strong, a priori, reason for considering O<sub>3</sub> and NO<sub>2</sub> together in epidemiological studies, rather than either of the two pollutants separately in single-pollutant models. This paper compares two approaches to this, using O<sub>x</sub>, defined as O<sub>3</sub> + NO<sub>2</sub>, as a single metric and also using O<sub>3</sub> and NO<sub>2</sub> together in two-pollutant models. We hypothesised that the magnitude of the association between O<sub>x</sub> and daily mortality would be greater than for NO<sub>2</sub> and O<sub>3</sub> individually. Using collocated hourly measurements for O<sub>3</sub> and NO<sub>2</sub> in London, from 2000 to 2005, we carried out a time series analysis of daily mortality. We investigated O<sub>3</sub>, NO<sub>2</sub> and O<sub>x</sub> individually in single-pollutant Poisson regression models and NO<sub>2</sub> and O<sub>3</sub> jointly in two-pollutant models in both all-year and season-specific analyses. We observed larger associations for mean 24-h concentrations of O<sub>x</sub> (1.30 % increase in mortality per 10 ppb) than for O<sub>3</sub> (0.87 %) and NO<sub>2</sub> (0 %) individually. However, when analysed jointly in two-pollutant models, associations for O<sub>3</sub> (1.54 %) and NO<sub>2</sub> (1.07 %) were comparable to the O<sub>x</sub> association. Season-specific analyses broadly followed this pattern irrespective of whether the O<sub>x</sub> concentrations were driven by O<sub>3</sub> production (summer) or depletion (winter). This novel approach in air pollution epidemiology captures the simultaneous impact of both oxidants whilst avoiding many of the statistical issues associated with two-pollutant models and potentially simplifies health impact calculations.
